| **placeholders** | {'cycle_num': 5, 'max_num_implement': 2, 'description': "chat_env.env_dict['task_description']", 'reviewed_process_text': "\n  \n  \n    \n      \n      \n      \n      \n      \n        \n          \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n            \n              \n            \n            \n              \n            \n          \n          \n            \n              \n            \n            \n              \n            \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n      \n    \n    \n      \n    \n  \n", 'cycle_index': 2, 'task': 'Module 3: Admission to Acute Care\nThis module identifies best practices for acute inpatient admissions (as described in recommendation\n2.4.2 for the specific group of TIA patients who should be admitted). Module 3a provides\nrecommendations for acute inpatient treatment, and module 3b provides recommendations for the\nprevention of secondary complications, which should be initiated in the acute care setting but also be\nconsidered as ongoing activities. All patients should be given appropriate cross-continuum\nprevention assessment and therapies (Modules 5 and 10). The Ontario Stroke Network revised the\ndefinition of a stroke unit “A geographical unit with identifiable co-located beds (eg 5A -7, 5A-8,\n5A-9, 5A-10, 5A-11) that are occupied by stroke patients 75% of the time and has a dedicated\ninterprofessional team with expertise in stroke care with the following professionals at a minimum\nnursing, physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech language pathologist”.) Ontario Stroke\nNetwork 2015\nModule 3a: Acute Care Treatment\nModule 3a Recommended Practices \n3.1 Stroke units\n3.1.1 Patients should be admitted to a specialized, geographically\ndefined hospital unit dedicated to the management of stroke patients\nA geographical unit with identifiable co-located beds (eg 5A -7, 5A-\n8, 5A-9, 5A-10, 5A-11) that are occupied by stroke patients 75% of\nthe time and has a dedicated inter-professional team with expertise in\nstroke care with the following professionals at a minimum nursing,\nphysiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech language pathologist”.\n• This recommendation is in accordance with the HQO Effectiveness\nof Stroke Unit Care: A Special Report, which concluded (61):\nModerate quality evidence showed that persons admitted to a stroke\nunit had a significant reduction in death and the combined outcome\nof death or institutionalization, and a nonsignificant reduction in\ninstitutionalization. Low quality evidence showed that patients\nadmitted to a stroke unit had a significant reduction in the combined\noutcome of death or dependency and length of hospital stay and a\nnonsignificant reduction in the outcome of dependency\n3.1.2 The core stroke unit team should consist of health care\nprofessionals with stroke expertise in medicine, nursing, occupational\ntherapy, physiotherapy, speech-language pathology, social work, and\nclinical nutrition (a dietitian)\n3.1.3 To have the necessary stroke expertise, the health care\nprofessionals on the core stroke unit team should be individuals who\nspend the vast majority of their time treating stroke patients and\nregularly complete education about stroke care\n3.1.4 Patients should have access to a specialized interprofessional\nteam 7 days a week\n3.1.5 Physiotherapy, speech-language pathology, and occupational\ntherapy team members should assess stroke patients within 48 hours\nof admission to hospital and formulate a management plan\n3.2 Early mobilization\n3.2.1 All stroke patients admitted to hospital with acute stroke should\nbe mobilized early(between 24 hours and 48 hours of stroke onset),\nunless contraindicated\nFrequent out-of-bed activity in the very early time frame (within 24\nhours of stroke onset) is not recommended Mobilization may be\nreasonable for some patients with acute stroke in the very early time\nframe and clinical judgement should be used.\n3.3 Assessment\n3.3.1 Clinicians should use standardized, valid assessment tools to\nevaluate patients’ stroke-related impairments and functional status\n3.3.2 AlphaFIM should be completed on or by day 3 after\nadmission(target day 3, admission day is day 1)\n3.3.3 All stroke patients should be assessed for risk of developing\nvenous thromboembolism\n3.3.4 Early mobilization and adequate hydration should be encouraged\nfor all acute stroke patients to help prevent venous thromboembolism\n3.3.5 The nutrition and hydration status of stroke patients should be\nassessed within the first 48 hours of admission using a valid screening\ntool. Stroke patients with nutritional concerns, hydration deficits,\ndysphagia, or other comorbidities should be referred to a dietitian.\nReferral to a dietitian should be made within 7 days of admission for\nrecommendations and for consideration of enteral nutrition support for\npatients who are unable to meet nutritional and fluid requirements\n3.4 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke\n3.5 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies\n3.5.1 All patients, whether admitted to in-hospital rehabilitation or\ndischarged, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary\nprevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)\nAbbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke\nManagement; CSBPR, Canadian Best Practices Recommendations; FIM, Functional Independence Measure; HQO, Health Quality Ontario;\nOSN, Ontario Stroke Network; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack.\n\nThe following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.\n\nModule 3a Implementation Considerations\nGeneral considerations\n• All hospitals providing stroke/TIA care should ensure that the interprofessional stroke team uses standardized, validated\nassessment tools; where possible, these tools should be in electronic format linked to the EHR\n• Patients should be screened/assessed for diabetes, dental issues, cognitive impairment, and depression upon\npresentation to the ED, and the results should be forwarded to the TIA clinic for follow-up\n• Hospitals should ensure adequate staffing 7 days per week\nAbbreviations: ED, emergency department; EHR, electronic health record; TIA, transient ischemic attack.', 'suggestions': "Problem: The activity 'Encourage early mobilization between 24-48 hours of stroke onset unless contraindicated; avoid frequent out-of-bed activity within first 24 hours unless clinically justified' with id='activity7' is placed after the parallel gateway with id='parallelgateway1', but logically, this activity should be performed in parallel with other early assessment and intervention activities within the first 48 hours of admission.\n\nSuggested modification: Move the activity with id='activity7' into a new branch within the parallel gateway with id='parallelgateway1', so that early mobilization is considered alongside other early assessment and intervention activities.\n\nReason: Early mobilization is a time-sensitive intervention that should occur in parallel with other assessments and management plans within the first 48 hours of admission, not after all other parallel activities are completed. This ensures that mobilization is not delayed and aligns with best practice guidelines.", 'format': "\nWhen the process starts, please output ''\nAn activity is represented as follows:\n\nThe exclusive gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nThe parallel gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nThe inclusive gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nAt the end of the process, please output ''\n\nThere are a few requirements that should be noted when generating process text:\n    1) role, action, objects and id in an activity represent the subject of the activity, the activity behavior, the items needed to perform in the activity and the activity id, respectively.\n    2) There are at least two branches within the exclusive gateway and the parallel gateway.\n    3) Activity, gateway, and branch id attributes must be unique.\n    4) When the branch in the exclusive gateway has a condition, fill the condition into the condition attribute. When the branch unconditional within the exclusive gateway, the condition attribute of the branch =''. However, all branches within a exclusive gateway can only be conditional, or both unconditional.\n    5) The branch in the parallel gateway has no condition attribute.\n    6) Each branch in the inclusive gateway must have condition.\n    7) There must be at least one activity inside the branch tag.\n    8) The activity of a sequential relation need not be represented by a gateway, that is, there is no 'sequenceGateway' label.\n", 'examples': ' '} |

Your main responsibilities include process generation, process refinement, process review and so on, guided by team leader. | **user_role_prompt** | You're a process design reviewer. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer. You are familiar with exclusive gateway, parallel gateway and inclusive gateway in BPMN. Your main responsibilities include give suggestion to the process. Here is a new customer's task: {task}. To complete the task, I will give you one or more instructions, and you must help me to write a specific solution that appropriately solves the requested instruction based on your expertise and my needs. |
| **task_prompt** | Module 3: Admission to Acute Care This module identifies best practices for acute inpatient admissions (as described in recommendation 2.4.2 for the specific group of TIA patients who should be admitted). Module 3a provides recommendations for acute inpatient treatment, and module 3b provides recommendations for the prevention of secondary complications, which should be initiated in the acute care setting but also be considered as ongoing activities. All patients should be given appropriate cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies (Modules 5 and 10). The Ontario Stroke Network revised the definition of a stroke unit “A geographical unit with identifiable co-located beds (eg 5A -7, 5A-8, 5A-9, 5A-10, 5A-11) that are occupied by stroke patients 75% of the time and has a dedicated interprofessional team with expertise in stroke care with the following professionals at a minimum nursing, physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech language pathologist”.) Ontario Stroke Network 2015 Module 3a: Acute Care Treatment Module 3a Recommended Practices  3.1 Stroke units 3.1.1 Patients should be admitted to a specialized, geographically defined hospital unit dedicated to the management of stroke patients A geographical unit with identifiable co-located beds (eg 5A -7, 5A- 8, 5A-9, 5A-10, 5A-11) that are occupied by stroke patients 75% of the time and has a dedicated inter-professional team with expertise in stroke care with the following professionals at a minimum nursing, physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech language pathologist”. • This recommendation is in accordance with the HQO Effectiveness of Stroke Unit Care: A Special Report, which concluded (61): Moderate quality evidence showed that persons admitted to a stroke unit had a significant reduction in death and the combined outcome of death or institutionalization, and a nonsignificant reduction in institutionalization. Low quality evidence showed that patients admitted to a stroke unit had a significant reduction in the combined outcome of death or dependency and length of hospital stay and a nonsignificant reduction in the outcome of dependency 3.1.2 The core stroke unit team should consist of health care professionals with stroke expertise in medicine, nursing, occupational therapy, physiotherapy, speech-language pathology, social work, and clinical nutrition (a dietitian) 3.1.3 To have the necessary stroke expertise, the health care professionals on the core stroke unit team should be individuals who spend the vast majority of their time treating stroke patients and regularly complete education about stroke care 3.1.4 Patients should have access to a specialized interprofessional team 7 days a week 3.1.5 Physiotherapy, speech-language pathology, and occupational therapy team members should assess stroke patients within 48 hours of admission to hospital and formulate a management plan 3.2 Early mobilization 3.2.1 All stroke patients admitted to hospital with acute stroke should be mobilized early(between 24 hours and 48 hours of stroke onset), unless contraindicated Frequent out-of-bed activity in the very early time frame (within 24 hours of stroke onset) is not recommended Mobilization may be reasonable for some patients with acute stroke in the very early time frame and clinical judgement should be used. 3.3 Assessment 3.3.1 Clinicians should use standardized, valid assessment tools to evaluate patients’ stroke-related impairments and functional status 3.3.2 AlphaFIM should be completed on or by day 3 after admission(target day 3, admission day is day 1) 3.3.3 All stroke patients should be assessed for risk of developing venous thromboembolism 3.3.4 Early mobilization and adequate hydration should be encouraged for all acute stroke patients to help prevent venous thromboembolism 3.3.5 The nutrition and hydration status of stroke patients should be assessed within the first 48 hours of admission using a valid screening tool. Stroke patients with nutritional concerns, hydration deficits, dysphagia, or other comorbidities should be referred to a dietitian. Referral to a dietitian should be made within 7 days of admission for recommendations and for consideration of enteral nutrition support for patients who are unable to meet nutritional and fluid requirements 3.4 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke 3.5 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies 3.5.1 All patients, whether admitted to in-hospital rehabilitation or discharged, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10) Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management; CSBPR, Canadian Best Practices Recommendations; FIM, Functional Independence Measure; HQO, Health Quality Ontario; OSN, Ontario Stroke Network; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack. The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel. Module 3a Implementation Considerations General considerations • All hospitals providing stroke/TIA care should ensure that the interprofessional stroke team uses standardized, validated assessment tools; where possible, these tools should be in electronic format linked to the EHR • Patients should be screened/assessed for diabetes, dental issues, cognitive impairment, and depression upon presentation to the ED, and the results should be forwarded to the TIA clinic for follow-up • Hospitals should ensure adequate staffing 7 days per week Abbreviations: ED, emergency department; EHR, electronic health record; TIA, transient ischemic attack. |
| **with_task_specify** | False |
| **memory** | current memory not loaded |
| **model_type** | ModelType.GPT_4o1 |

[2025-30-06 12:14:24 INFO] flask app.py did not start for online log
[2025-30-06 12:14:24 INFO] Process design reviewer: **[Start Chat]**

[You're a process design expert. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer.
You are familiar with exclusive gateway, parallel gateway and inclusive gateway in BPMN. Your main responsibilities include process generation, process refinement, process review and so on, guided by team leader.
You model the process of a clinical practice guideline to a clinical pathway.
Here is a new customer's task: Module 3: Admission to Acute Care
This module identifies best practices for acute inpatient admissions (as described in recommendation
2.4.2 for the specific group of TIA patients who should be admitted). Module 3a provides
recommendations for acute inpatient treatment, and module 3b provides recommendations for the
prevention of secondary complications, which should be initiated in the acute care setting but also be
considered as ongoing activities. All patients should be given appropriate cross-continuum
prevention assessment and therapies (Modules 5 and 10). The Ontario Stroke Network revised the
definition of a stroke unit “A geographical unit with identifiable co-located beds (eg 5A -7, 5A-8,
5A-9, 5A-10, 5A-11) that are occupied by stroke patients 75% of the time and has a dedicated
interprofessional team with expertise in stroke care with the following professionals at a minimum
nursing, physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech language pathologist”.) Ontario Stroke
Network 2015
Module 3a: Acute Care Treatment
Module 3a Recommended Practices 
3.1 Stroke units
3.1.1 Patients should be admitted to a specialized, geographically
defined hospital unit dedicated to the management of stroke patients
A geographical unit with identifiable co-located beds (eg 5A -7, 5A-
8, 5A-9, 5A-10, 5A-11) that are occupied by stroke patients 75% of
the time and has a dedicated inter-professional team with expertise in
stroke care with the following professionals at a minimum nursing,
physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech language pathologist”.
• This recommendation is in accordance with the HQO Effectiveness
of Stroke Unit Care: A Special Report, which concluded (61):
Moderate quality evidence showed that persons admitted to a stroke
unit had a significant reduction in death and the combined outcome
of death or institutionalization, and a nonsignificant reduction in
institutionalization. Low quality evidence showed that patients
admitted to a stroke unit had a significant reduction in the combined
outcome of death or dependency and length of hospital stay and a
nonsignificant reduction in the outcome of dependency
3.1.2 The core stroke unit team should consist of health care
professionals with stroke expertise in medicine, nursing, occupational
therapy, physiotherapy, speech-language pathology, social work, and
clinical nutrition (a dietitian)
3.1.3 To have the necessary stroke expertise, the health care
professionals on the core stroke unit team should be individuals who
spend the vast majority of their time treating stroke patients and
regularly complete education about stroke care
3.1.4 Patients should have access to a specialized interprofessional
team 7 days a week
3.1.5 Physiotherapy, speech-language pathology, and occupational
therapy team members should assess stroke patients within 48 hours
of admission to hospital and formulate a management plan
3.2 Early mobilization
3.2.1 All stroke patients admitted to hospital with acute stroke should
be mobilized early(between 24 hours and 48 hours of stroke onset),
unless contraindicated
Frequent out-of-bed activity in the very early time frame (within 24
hours of stroke onset) is not recommended Mobilization may be
reasonable for some patients with acute stroke in the very early time
frame and clinical judgement should be used.
3.3 Assessment
3.3.1 Clinicians should use standardized, valid assessment tools to
evaluate patients’ stroke-related impairments and functional status
3.3.2 AlphaFIM should be completed on or by day 3 after
admission(target day 3, admission day is day 1)
3.3.3 All stroke patients should be assessed for risk of developing
venous thromboembolism
3.3.4 Early mobilization and adequate hydration should be encouraged
for all acute stroke patients to help prevent venous thromboembolism
3.3.5 The nutrition and hydration status of stroke patients should be
assessed within the first 48 hours of admission using a valid screening
tool. Stroke patients with nutritional concerns, hydration deficits,
dysphagia, or other comorbidities should be referred to a dietitian.
Referral to a dietitian should be made within 7 days of admission for
recommendations and for consideration of enteral nutrition support for
patients who are unable to meet nutritional and fluid requirements
3.4 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke
3.5 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies
3.5.1 All patients, whether admitted to in-hospital rehabilitation or
discharged, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary
prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)
Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke
Management; CSBPR, Canadian Best Practices Recommendations; FIM, Functional Independence Measure; HQO, Health Quality Ontario;
OSN, Ontario Stroke Network; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack.

The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.

Module 3a Implementation Considerations
General considerations
• All hospitals providing stroke/TIA care should ensure that the interprofessional stroke team uses standardized, validated
assessment tools; where possible, these tools should be in electronic format linked to the EHR
• Patients should be screened/assessed for diabetes, dental issues, cognitive impairment, and depression upon
presentation to the ED, and the results should be forwarded to the TIA clinic for follow-up
• Hospitals should ensure adequate staffing 7 days per week
Abbreviations: ED, emergency department; EHR, electronic health record; TIA, transient ischemic attack..
To complete the task, I will give you one or more instructions, and you must help me to write a specific solution that appropriately solves the requested instruction based on your expertise and my needs.]

task: Module 3: Admission to Acute Care
This module identifies best practices for acute inpatient admissions (as described in recommendation
2.4.2 for the specific group of TIA patients who should be admitted). Module 3a provides
recommendations for acute inpatient treatment, and module 3b provides recommendations for the
prevention of secondary complications, which should be initiated in the acute care setting but also be
considered as ongoing activities. All patients should be given appropriate cross-continuum
prevention assessment and therapies (Modules 5 and 10). The Ontario Stroke Network revised the
definition of a stroke unit “A geographical unit with identifiable co-located beds (eg 5A -7, 5A-8,
5A-9, 5A-10, 5A-11) that are occupied by stroke patients 75% of the time and has a dedicated
interprofessional team with expertise in stroke care with the following professionals at a minimum
nursing, physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech language pathologist”.) Ontario Stroke
Network 2015
Module 3a: Acute Care Treatment
Module 3a Recommended Practices 
3.1 Stroke units
3.1.1 Patients should be admitted to a specialized, geographically
defined hospital unit dedicated to the management of stroke patients
A geographical unit with identifiable co-located beds (eg 5A -7, 5A-
8, 5A-9, 5A-10, 5A-11) that are occupied by stroke patients 75% of
the time and has a dedicated inter-professional team with expertise in
stroke care with the following professionals at a minimum nursing,
physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech language pathologist”.
• This recommendation is in accordance with the HQO Effectiveness
of Stroke Unit Care: A Special Report, which concluded (61):
Moderate quality evidence showed that persons admitted to a stroke
unit had a significant reduction in death and the combined outcome
of death or institutionalization, and a nonsignificant reduction in
institutionalization. Low quality evidence showed that patients
admitted to a stroke unit had a significant reduction in the combined
outcome of death or dependency and length of hospital stay and a
nonsignificant reduction in the outcome of dependency
3.1.2 The core stroke unit team should consist of health care
professionals with stroke expertise in medicine, nursing, occupational
therapy, physiotherapy, speech-language pathology, social work, and
clinical nutrition (a dietitian)
3.1.3 To have the necessary stroke expertise, the health care
professionals on the core stroke unit team should be individuals who
spend the vast majority of their time treating stroke patients and
regularly complete education about stroke care
3.1.4 Patients should have access to a specialized interprofessional
team 7 days a week
3.1.5 Physiotherapy, speech-language pathology, and occupational
therapy team members should assess stroke patients within 48 hours
of admission to hospital and formulate a management plan
3.2 Early mobilization
3.2.1 All stroke patients admitted to hospital with acute stroke should
be mobilized early(between 24 hours and 48 hours of stroke onset),
unless contraindicated
Frequent out-of-bed activity in the very early time frame (within 24
hours of stroke onset) is not recommended Mobilization may be
reasonable for some patients with acute stroke in the very early time
frame and clinical judgement should be used.
3.3 Assessment
3.3.1 Clinicians should use standardized, valid assessment tools to
evaluate patients’ stroke-related impairments and functional status
3.3.2 AlphaFIM should be completed on or by day 3 after
admission(target day 3, admission day is day 1)
3.3.3 All stroke patients should be assessed for risk of developing
venous thromboembolism
3.3.4 Early mobilization and adequate hydration should be encouraged
for all acute stroke patients to help prevent venous thromboembolism
3.3.5 The nutrition and hydration status of stroke patients should be
assessed within the first 48 hours of admission using a valid screening
tool. Stroke patients with nutritional concerns, hydration deficits,
dysphagia, or other comorbidities should be referred to a dietitian.
Referral to a dietitian should be made within 7 days of admission for
recommendations and for consideration of enteral nutrition support for
patients who are unable to meet nutritional and fluid requirements
3.4 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke
3.5 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies
3.5.1 All patients, whether admitted to in-hospital rehabilitation or
discharged, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary
prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)
Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke
Management; CSBPR, Canadian Best Practices Recommendations; FIM, Functional Independence Measure; HQO, Health Quality Ontario;
OSN, Ontario Stroke Network; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack.

The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.

Module 3a Implementation Considerations
General considerations
• All hospitals providing stroke/TIA care should ensure that the interprofessional stroke team uses standardized, validated
assessment tools; where possible, these tools should be in electronic format linked to the EHR
• Patients should be screened/assessed for diabetes, dental issues, cognitive impairment, and depression upon
presentation to the ED, and the results should be forwarded to the TIA clinic for follow-up
• Hospitals should ensure adequate staffing 7 days per week
Abbreviations: ED, emergency department; EHR, electronic health record; TIA, transient ischemic attack.
process text: 
<process>
  <activity role='ED clinician' action='Screen/assess for diabetes, dental issues, cognitive impairment, and depression upon ED presentation and forward results to TIA clinic for follow-up' objects='patient, screening tools' id='activity1'/>
  <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway1'>
    <branch condition='Meets criteria for acute inpatient admission (per recommendation 2.4.2)' id='branch1'>
      <activity role='admitting clinician' action='Admit patient to specialized, geographically defined stroke unit (co-located beds, 75% stroke occupancy)' objects='patient, stroke unit' id='activity2'/>
      <activity role='hospital administration' action='Ensure dedicated interprofessional stroke team with expertise in stroke care (nursing, physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech-language pathology, medicine, social work, dietitian)' objects='staffing schedule' id='activity3'/>
      <activity role='hospital administration' action='Ensure interprofessional stroke team available 7 days a week' objects='staffing schedule' id='activity4'/>
      <activity role='hospital administration' action='Ensure use of standardized, validated assessment tools (preferably electronic and linked to EHR)' objects='assessment tools, EHR' id='activity5'/>
      <parallelGateway id='parallelgateway1'>
        <branch id='branch2'>
          <activity role='physiotherapist, occupational therapist, speech-language pathologist' action='Assess patient within 48 hours of admission' objects='patient, assessment tools' id='activity6-1'/>
          <activity role='physiotherapist, occupational therapist, speech-language pathologist' action='Formulate management plan' objects='patient, assessment results' id='activity6-2'/>
        </branch>
        <branch id='branch3'>
          <activity role='clinician' action='Use standardized, valid assessment tools to evaluate stroke-related impairments and functional status' objects='patient, assessment tools' id='activity8'/>
        </branch>
        <branch id='branch4'>
          <activity role='clinician' action='Complete AlphaFIM assessment on or by day 3 after admission (admission day is day 1)' objects='patient, AlphaFIM tool' id='activity9'/>
        </branch>
        <branch id='branch5'>
          <activity role='clinician' action='Assess all stroke patients for risk of developing venous thromboembolism' objects='patient, risk assessment tool' id='activity10'/>
        </branch>
        <branch id='branch6'>
          <activity role='clinical team' action='Encourage early mobilization and adequate hydration to help prevent venous thromboembolism' objects='patient' id='activity11'/>
        </branch>
        <branch id='branch7'>
          <parallelGateway id='parallelgateway2'>
            <branch id='branch7-1'>
              <activity role='clinician' action='Assess nutrition status within first 48 hours of admission using valid screening tool' objects='patient, screening tool' id='activity12-1'/>
            </branch>
            <branch id='branch7-2'>
              <activity role='clinician' action='Assess hydration status within first 48 hours of admission using valid screening tool' objects='patient, screening tool' id='activity12-2'/>
            </branch>
          </parallelGateway>
          <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway2'>
            <branch condition='Nutritional concerns, hydration deficits, dysphagia, or comorbidities present' id='branch8'>
              <activity role='clinician' action='Refer patient to dietitian within 7 days of admission for recommendations and consideration of enteral nutrition support if unable to meet nutritional/fluid requirements' objects='patient, referral' id='activity13'/>
            </branch>
            <branch condition='No nutritional concerns, hydration deficits, dysphagia, or comorbidities' id='branch9'>
              <activity role='clinician' action='Continue standard monitoring' objects='patient' id='activity14'/>
            </branch>
          </exclusiveGateway>
        </branch>
        <branch id='branch8'>
          <activity role='clinical team' action='Provide appropriate cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10) to all patients, whether admitted to in-hospital rehabilitation or discharged' objects='patient, prevention protocols' id='activity15'/>
        </branch>
      </parallelGateway>
      <activity role='clinical team' action='Encourage early mobilization between 24-48 hours of stroke onset unless contraindicated; avoid frequent out-of-bed activity within first 24 hours unless clinically justified' objects='patient' id='activity7'/>
    </branch>
    <branch condition='Does not meet criteria for acute inpatient admission (e.g., TIA or minor/nondisabling stroke)' id='branch10'>
      <activity role='clinician' action='Do not apply acute inpatient stroke unit recommendations; proceed with alternative care pathway' objects='patient' id='activity16'/>
    </branch>
  </exclusiveGateway>
</process>
suggestion:
Problem: The activity 'Encourage early mobilization between 24-48 hours of stroke onset unless contraindicated; avoid frequent out-of-bed activity within first 24 hours unless clinically justified' with id='activity7' is placed after the parallel gateway with id='parallelgateway1', but logically, this activity should be performed in parallel with other early assessment and intervention activities within the first 48 hours of admission.

Suggested modification: Move the activity with id='activity7' into a new branch within the parallel gateway with id='parallelgateway1', so that early mobilization is considered alongside other early assessment and intervention activities.

Reason: Early mobilization is a time-sensitive intervention that should occur in parallel with other assessments and management plans within the first 48 hours of admission, not after all other parallel activities are completed. This ensures that mobilization is not delayed and aligns with best practice guidelines.
You need to modify the process text according to the suggestions and output it.
Be careful not to change the format:

When the process starts, please output '<process>'
An activity is represented as follows:
<activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
The exclusive gateway is represented as follows:
<exclusiveGateway id=''>
  <branch condition='' id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
  <branch condition='' id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
</exclusiveGateway>
The parallel gateway is represented as follows:
<parallelGateway id=''>
  <branch id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
  <branch id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
</parallelGateway>
The inclusive gateway is represented as follows:
<inclusiveGateway id=''>
  <branch condition='' id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
  <branch condition='' id=''>
    <activity role='' action='' objects='' id=''/>
  </branch>
</inclusiveGateway>
At the end of the process, please output '</process>'

There are a few requirements that should be noted when generating process text:
    1) role, action, objects and id in an activity represent the subject of the activity, the activity behavior, the items needed to perform in the activity and the activity id, respectively.
    2) There are at least two branches within the exclusive gateway and the parallel gateway.
    3) Activity, gateway, and branch id attributes must be unique.
    4) When the branch in the exclusive gateway has a condition, fill the condition into the condition attribute. When the branch unconditional within the exclusive gateway, the condition attribute of the branch =''. However, all branches within a exclusive gateway can only be conditional, or both unconditional.
    5) The branch in the parallel gateway has no condition attribute.
    6) Each branch in the inclusive gateway must have condition.
    7) There must be at least one activity inside the branch tag.
    8) The activity of a sequential relation need not be represented by a gateway, that is, there is no 'sequenceGateway' label.

[2025-30-06 12:14:40 INFO] Process design expert: **Process design expert<->Process design reviewer on : ProcessReview, turn 0**

[You're a process design reviewer. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer.
You are familiar with exclusive gateway, parallel gateway and inclusive gateway in BPMN. Your main responsibilities include give suggestion to the process.
Here is a new customer's task: Module 3: Admission to Acute Care
This module identifies best practices for acute inpatient admissions (as described in recommendation
2.4.2 for the specific group of TIA patients who should be admitted). Module 3a provides
recommendations for acute inpatient treatment, and module 3b provides recommendations for the
prevention of secondary complications, which should be initiated in the acute care setting but also be
considered as ongoing activities. All patients should be given appropriate cross-continuum
prevention assessment and therapies (Modules 5 and 10). The Ontario Stroke Network revised the
definition of a stroke unit “A geographical unit with identifiable co-located beds (eg 5A -7, 5A-8,
5A-9, 5A-10, 5A-11) that are occupied by stroke patients 75% of the time and has a dedicated
interprofessional team with expertise in stroke care with the following professionals at a minimum
nursing, physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech language pathologist”.) Ontario Stroke
Network 2015
Module 3a: Acute Care Treatment
Module 3a Recommended Practices 
3.1 Stroke units
3.1.1 Patients should be admitted to a specialized, geographically
defined hospital unit dedicated to the management of stroke patients
A geographical unit with identifiable co-located beds (eg 5A -7, 5A-
8, 5A-9, 5A-10, 5A-11) that are occupied by stroke patients 75% of
the time and has a dedicated inter-professional team with expertise in
stroke care with the following professionals at a minimum nursing,
physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech language pathologist”.
• This recommendation is in accordance with the HQO Effectiveness
of Stroke Unit Care: A Special Report, which concluded (61):
Moderate quality evidence showed that persons admitted to a stroke
unit had a significant reduction in death and the combined outcome
of death or institutionalization, and a nonsignificant reduction in
institutionalization. Low quality evidence showed that patients
admitted to a stroke unit had a significant reduction in the combined
outcome of death or dependency and length of hospital stay and a
nonsignificant reduction in the outcome of dependency
3.1.2 The core stroke unit team should consist of health care
professionals with stroke expertise in medicine, nursing, occupational
therapy, physiotherapy, speech-language pathology, social work, and
clinical nutrition (a dietitian)
3.1.3 To have the necessary stroke expertise, the health care
professionals on the core stroke unit team should be individuals who
spend the vast majority of their time treating stroke patients and
regularly complete education about stroke care
3.1.4 Patients should have access to a specialized interprofessional
team 7 days a week
3.1.5 Physiotherapy, speech-language pathology, and occupational
therapy team members should assess stroke patients within 48 hours
of admission to hospital and formulate a management plan
3.2 Early mobilization
3.2.1 All stroke patients admitted to hospital with acute stroke should
be mobilized early(between 24 hours and 48 hours of stroke onset),
unless contraindicated
Frequent out-of-bed activity in the very early time frame (within 24
hours of stroke onset) is not recommended Mobilization may be
reasonable for some patients with acute stroke in the very early time
frame and clinical judgement should be used.
3.3 Assessment
3.3.1 Clinicians should use standardized, valid assessment tools to
evaluate patients’ stroke-related impairments and functional status
3.3.2 AlphaFIM should be completed on or by day 3 after
admission(target day 3, admission day is day 1)
3.3.3 All stroke patients should be assessed for risk of developing
venous thromboembolism
3.3.4 Early mobilization and adequate hydration should be encouraged
for all acute stroke patients to help prevent venous thromboembolism
3.3.5 The nutrition and hydration status of stroke patients should be
assessed within the first 48 hours of admission using a valid screening
tool. Stroke patients with nutritional concerns, hydration deficits,
dysphagia, or other comorbidities should be referred to a dietitian.
Referral to a dietitian should be made within 7 days of admission for
recommendations and for consideration of enteral nutrition support for
patients who are unable to meet nutritional and fluid requirements
3.4 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke
3.5 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies
3.5.1 All patients, whether admitted to in-hospital rehabilitation or
discharged, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary
prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)
Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke
Management; CSBPR, Canadian Best Practices Recommendations; FIM, Functional Independence Measure; HQO, Health Quality Ontario;
OSN, Ontario Stroke Network; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack.

The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.

Module 3a Implementation Considerations
General considerations
• All hospitals providing stroke/TIA care should ensure that the interprofessional stroke team uses standardized, validated
assessment tools; where possible, these tools should be in electronic format linked to the EHR
• Patients should be screened/assessed for diabetes, dental issues, cognitive impairment, and depression upon
presentation to the ED, and the results should be forwarded to the TIA clinic for follow-up
• Hospitals should ensure adequate staffing 7 days per week
Abbreviations: ED, emergency department; EHR, electronic health record; TIA, transient ischemic attack..
To complete the task, I will give you one or more instructions, and you must help me to write a specific solution that appropriately solves the requested instruction based on your expertise and my needs.]

  <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway1'>

          <exclusiveGateway id='exclusivegateway2'>
            <branch condition='Nutritional concerns, hydration deficits, dysphagia, or comorbidities present' id='branch8'>
              <activity role='clinician' action='Refer patient to dietitian within 7 days of admission for recommendations and consideration of enteral nutrition support if unable to meet nutritional/fluid requirements' objects='patient, referral' id='activity13'/>
            </branch>
            <branch condition='No nutritional concerns, hydration deficits, dysphagia, or comorbidities' id='branch9'>

            </branch>
          </exclusiveGateway>
        </branch>
        <branch id='branch8'>
          <activity role='clinical team' action='Provide appropriate cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10) to all patients, whether admitted to in-hospital rehabilitation or discharged' objects='patient, prevention protocols' id='activity15'/>
        </branch>
        <branch id='branch11'>
          <activity role='clinical team' action='Encourage early mobilization between 24-48 hours of stroke onset unless contraindicated; avoid frequent out-of-bed activity within first 24 hours unless clinically justified' objects='patient' id='activity7'/>
        </branch>
      </parallelGateway>
    </branch>

    </branch>
  </exclusiveGateway>
</process>

| **phase_prompt** | task: {task} process text: {reviewed_process_text} Please check whether there are logic problems and format problems of activities and gateways in the process text, such as the reverse of the order of activities, unreasonable design of gateways, and wrong order of activities or branches. For the modification scheme, the specific reason for modification and the details of the modification scheme should be explained. Here's a shipping process and some examples of checking for errors, you can refer but not copy:                                                                                                         example1:    Problem: The 'receiving package' activity with id='activity2' and the exclusive gateway with id='exclusivegateway1' are in the wrong order and logic error.    Suggested modification: Move the 'receiving package' activity with id='activity2' under the branch with id='branch1' of the exclusive gateway with id='exclusivegateway1'.    Reason: After the sender chooses to pick up the package, the Courier can perform the activities of accepting the package. example2:    Problem: The activities are not a parallel relation in the parallel gateway with id='parallelgateway1'.    Suggested modification: In the parallel gateway with id='parallelgateway1', change the activities from a parallel structure to a sequential structure.    Reason: Logically, 'packing and handling packages' and 'transport and distribution packages' are not parallel relationships. example3:    Problem: The 'end of service' activity with id='activity7' and the 'sign for parcel' activity with id='activity8' are in the wrong order.    Suggested modification: Swap the position of the 'end of service' activity with id='activity7' and the 'sign for parcel' activity with id='activity8'.    Reason: Only after the recipient sign for package can the express company terminate the service. example4:    Problem: The sequence gateway with id='sequencegateway1' is incorrectly formatted.    Suggested modification: Remove the gateway label of the sequence gateway with id='sequencegateway1'.    Reason: Sequential activities need not be contained under a gateway. When making recommendations, don't forget the format of the process text: {format} Please note: 1) If you think there is an error in the process text, output the error as requested. Please Just list one for me.  2) If you think there is no formatting or logical error in the process text, please just output 'There is no error in the process text.' and don't say anything else. |
| **phase_name** | GiveSuggestion |
| **assistant_role_prompt** | You're a process design reviewer. Now, we share a common interest in collaborating to successfully complete a task assigned by a new customer. You are familiar with exclusive gateway, parallel gateway and inclusive gateway in BPMN. Your main responsibilities include give suggestion to the process. Here is a new customer's task: {task}. To complete the task, I will give you one or more instructions, and you must help me to write a specific solution that appropriately solves the requested instruction based on your expertise and my needs. |

Your main responsibilities will include guiding the process design expert through process generation, process refinement, and so on. Here is a new customer's task: {task}. To complete the task, I will give you one or more instructions, and you must help me to write a specific solution that appropriately solves the requested instruction based on your expertise and my needs. |

| **placeholders** | {'cycle_num': 5, 'max_num_implement': 2, 'description': "chat_env.env_dict['task_description']", 'reviewed_process_text': "\n  \n  \n    \n      \n      \n      \n      \n      \n        \n          \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n            \n              \n            \n            \n              \n            \n          \n          \n            \n              \n            \n            \n              \n            \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n        \n          \n        \n      \n    \n    \n      \n    \n  \n", 'cycle_index': 3, 'task': 'Module 3: Admission to Acute Care\nThis module identifies best practices for acute inpatient admissions (as described in recommendation\n2.4.2 for the specific group of TIA patients who should be admitted). Module 3a provides\nrecommendations for acute inpatient treatment, and module 3b provides recommendations for the\nprevention of secondary complications, which should be initiated in the acute care setting but also be\nconsidered as ongoing activities. All patients should be given appropriate cross-continuum\nprevention assessment and therapies (Modules 5 and 10). The Ontario Stroke Network revised the\ndefinition of a stroke unit “A geographical unit with identifiable co-located beds (eg 5A -7, 5A-8,\n5A-9, 5A-10, 5A-11) that are occupied by stroke patients 75% of the time and has a dedicated\ninterprofessional team with expertise in stroke care with the following professionals at a minimum\nnursing, physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech language pathologist”.) Ontario Stroke\nNetwork 2015\nModule 3a: Acute Care Treatment\nModule 3a Recommended Practices \n3.1 Stroke units\n3.1.1 Patients should be admitted to a specialized, geographically\ndefined hospital unit dedicated to the management of stroke patients\nA geographical unit with identifiable co-located beds (eg 5A -7, 5A-\n8, 5A-9, 5A-10, 5A-11) that are occupied by stroke patients 75% of\nthe time and has a dedicated inter-professional team with expertise in\nstroke care with the following professionals at a minimum nursing,\nphysiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech language pathologist”.\n• This recommendation is in accordance with the HQO Effectiveness\nof Stroke Unit Care: A Special Report, which concluded (61):\nModerate quality evidence showed that persons admitted to a stroke\nunit had a significant reduction in death and the combined outcome\nof death or institutionalization, and a nonsignificant reduction in\ninstitutionalization. Low quality evidence showed that patients\nadmitted to a stroke unit had a significant reduction in the combined\noutcome of death or dependency and length of hospital stay and a\nnonsignificant reduction in the outcome of dependency\n3.1.2 The core stroke unit team should consist of health care\nprofessionals with stroke expertise in medicine, nursing, occupational\ntherapy, physiotherapy, speech-language pathology, social work, and\nclinical nutrition (a dietitian)\n3.1.3 To have the necessary stroke expertise, the health care\nprofessionals on the core stroke unit team should be individuals who\nspend the vast majority of their time treating stroke patients and\nregularly complete education about stroke care\n3.1.4 Patients should have access to a specialized interprofessional\nteam 7 days a week\n3.1.5 Physiotherapy, speech-language pathology, and occupational\ntherapy team members should assess stroke patients within 48 hours\nof admission to hospital and formulate a management plan\n3.2 Early mobilization\n3.2.1 All stroke patients admitted to hospital with acute stroke should\nbe mobilized early(between 24 hours and 48 hours of stroke onset),\nunless contraindicated\nFrequent out-of-bed activity in the very early time frame (within 24\nhours of stroke onset) is not recommended Mobilization may be\nreasonable for some patients with acute stroke in the very early time\nframe and clinical judgement should be used.\n3.3 Assessment\n3.3.1 Clinicians should use standardized, valid assessment tools to\nevaluate patients’ stroke-related impairments and functional status\n3.3.2 AlphaFIM should be completed on or by day 3 after\nadmission(target day 3, admission day is day 1)\n3.3.3 All stroke patients should be assessed for risk of developing\nvenous thromboembolism\n3.3.4 Early mobilization and adequate hydration should be encouraged\nfor all acute stroke patients to help prevent venous thromboembolism\n3.3.5 The nutrition and hydration status of stroke patients should be\nassessed within the first 48 hours of admission using a valid screening\ntool. Stroke patients with nutritional concerns, hydration deficits,\ndysphagia, or other comorbidities should be referred to a dietitian.\nReferral to a dietitian should be made within 7 days of admission for\nrecommendations and for consideration of enteral nutrition support for\npatients who are unable to meet nutritional and fluid requirements\n3.4 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke\n3.5 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies\n3.5.1 All patients, whether admitted to in-hospital rehabilitation or\ndischarged, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary\nprevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10)\nAbbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke\nManagement; CSBPR, Canadian Best Practices Recommendations; FIM, Functional Independence Measure; HQO, Health Quality Ontario;\nOSN, Ontario Stroke Network; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack.\n\nThe following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel.\n\nModule 3a Implementation Considerations\nGeneral considerations\n• All hospitals providing stroke/TIA care should ensure that the interprofessional stroke team uses standardized, validated\nassessment tools; where possible, these tools should be in electronic format linked to the EHR\n• Patients should be screened/assessed for diabetes, dental issues, cognitive impairment, and depression upon\npresentation to the ED, and the results should be forwarded to the TIA clinic for follow-up\n• Hospitals should ensure adequate staffing 7 days per week\nAbbreviations: ED, emergency department; EHR, electronic health record; TIA, transient ischemic attack.', 'suggestions': "Problem: The activity 'Encourage early mobilization between 24-48 hours of stroke onset unless contraindicated; avoid frequent out-of-bed activity within first 24 hours unless clinically justified' with id='activity7' is placed after the parallel gateway with id='parallelgateway1', but logically, this activity should be performed in parallel with other early assessment and intervention activities within the first 48 hours of admission.\n\nSuggested modification: Move the activity with id='activity7' into a new branch within the parallel gateway with id='parallelgateway1', so that early mobilization is considered alongside other early assessment and intervention activities.\n\nReason: Early mobilization is a time-sensitive intervention that should occur in parallel with other assessments and management plans within the first 48 hours of admission, not after all other parallel activities are completed. This ensures that mobilization is not delayed and aligns with best practice guidelines.", 'format': "\nWhen the process starts, please output ''\nAn activity is represented as follows:\n\nThe exclusive gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nThe parallel gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nThe inclusive gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nAt the end of the process, please output ''\n\nThere are a few requirements that should be noted when generating process text:\n    1) role, action, objects and id in an activity represent the subject of the activity, the activity behavior, the items needed to perform in the activity and the activity id, respectively.\n    2) There are at least two branches within the exclusive gateway and the parallel gateway.\n    3) Activity, gateway, and branch id attributes must be unique.\n    4) When the branch in the exclusive gateway has a condition, fill the condition into the condition attribute. When the branch unconditional within the exclusive gateway, the condition attribute of the branch =''. However, all branches within a exclusive gateway can only be conditional, or both unconditional.\n    5) The branch in the parallel gateway has no condition attribute.\n    6) Each branch in the inclusive gateway must have condition.\n    7) There must be at least one activity inside the branch tag.\n    8) The activity of a sequential relation need not be represented by a gateway, that is, there is no 'sequenceGateway' label.\n", 'examples': ' '} |

| **task_prompt** | Module 3: Admission to Acute Care This module identifies best practices for acute inpatient admissions (as described in recommendation 2.4.2 for the specific group of TIA patients who should be admitted). Module 3a provides recommendations for acute inpatient treatment, and module 3b provides recommendations for the prevention of secondary complications, which should be initiated in the acute care setting but also be considered as ongoing activities. All patients should be given appropriate cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies (Modules 5 and 10). The Ontario Stroke Network revised the definition of a stroke unit “A geographical unit with identifiable co-located beds (eg 5A -7, 5A-8, 5A-9, 5A-10, 5A-11) that are occupied by stroke patients 75% of the time and has a dedicated interprofessional team with expertise in stroke care with the following professionals at a minimum nursing, physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech language pathologist”.) Ontario Stroke Network 2015 Module 3a: Acute Care Treatment Module 3a Recommended Practices  3.1 Stroke units 3.1.1 Patients should be admitted to a specialized, geographically defined hospital unit dedicated to the management of stroke patients A geographical unit with identifiable co-located beds (eg 5A -7, 5A- 8, 5A-9, 5A-10, 5A-11) that are occupied by stroke patients 75% of the time and has a dedicated inter-professional team with expertise in stroke care with the following professionals at a minimum nursing, physiotherapy, occupational therapy, speech language pathologist”. • This recommendation is in accordance with the HQO Effectiveness of Stroke Unit Care: A Special Report, which concluded (61): Moderate quality evidence showed that persons admitted to a stroke unit had a significant reduction in death and the combined outcome of death or institutionalization, and a nonsignificant reduction in institutionalization. Low quality evidence showed that patients admitted to a stroke unit had a significant reduction in the combined outcome of death or dependency and length of hospital stay and a nonsignificant reduction in the outcome of dependency 3.1.2 The core stroke unit team should consist of health care professionals with stroke expertise in medicine, nursing, occupational therapy, physiotherapy, speech-language pathology, social work, and clinical nutrition (a dietitian) 3.1.3 To have the necessary stroke expertise, the health care professionals on the core stroke unit team should be individuals who spend the vast majority of their time treating stroke patients and regularly complete education about stroke care 3.1.4 Patients should have access to a specialized interprofessional team 7 days a week 3.1.5 Physiotherapy, speech-language pathology, and occupational therapy team members should assess stroke patients within 48 hours of admission to hospital and formulate a management plan 3.2 Early mobilization 3.2.1 All stroke patients admitted to hospital with acute stroke should be mobilized early(between 24 hours and 48 hours of stroke onset), unless contraindicated Frequent out-of-bed activity in the very early time frame (within 24 hours of stroke onset) is not recommended Mobilization may be reasonable for some patients with acute stroke in the very early time frame and clinical judgement should be used. 3.3 Assessment 3.3.1 Clinicians should use standardized, valid assessment tools to evaluate patients’ stroke-related impairments and functional status 3.3.2 AlphaFIM should be completed on or by day 3 after admission(target day 3, admission day is day 1) 3.3.3 All stroke patients should be assessed for risk of developing venous thromboembolism 3.3.4 Early mobilization and adequate hydration should be encouraged for all acute stroke patients to help prevent venous thromboembolism 3.3.5 The nutrition and hydration status of stroke patients should be assessed within the first 48 hours of admission using a valid screening tool. Stroke patients with nutritional concerns, hydration deficits, dysphagia, or other comorbidities should be referred to a dietitian. Referral to a dietitian should be made within 7 days of admission for recommendations and for consideration of enteral nutrition support for patients who are unable to meet nutritional and fluid requirements 3.4 Recommendations are not applicable to TIA or minor (nondisabling) stroke 3.5 Cross-continuum prevention assessment and therapies 3.5.1 All patients, whether admitted to in-hospital rehabilitation or discharged, should be given appropriate cross-continuum secondary prevention assessments and therapies (Modules 5 and 10) Abbreviations: AHA/ASA, American Heart Association/American Stroke Association; Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke Management; CSBPR, Canadian Best Practices Recommendations; FIM, Functional Independence Measure; HQO, Health Quality Ontario; OSN, Ontario Stroke Network; SIGN, Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network; TIA, transient ischemic attack. The following implementation considerations were noted by members of the expert advisory panel. Module 3a Implementation Considerations General considerations • All hospitals providing stroke/TIA care should ensure that the interprofessional stroke team uses standardized, validated assessment tools; where possible, these tools should be in electronic format linked to the EHR • Patients should be screened/assessed for diabetes, dental issues, cognitive impairment, and depression upon presentation to the ED, and the results should be forwarded to the TIA clinic for follow-up • Hospitals should ensure adequate staffing 7 days per week Abbreviations: ED, emergency department; EHR, electronic health record; TIA, transient ischemic attack. |
| **with_task_specify** | False |
| **memory** | current memory not loaded |
| **model_type** | ModelType.GPT_4o1 |

acute stroke in the very early time\nframe and clinical judgement should be used.\n3.3 Assessment\n3.3.1 Clinicians should use standardized, valid assessment tools to\nevaluate patients’ stroke-related impairments and functional status\n3.3.2 AlphaFIM should be completed on or by day 3 after\nadmission(target day 3, admission day is day 1)\n3.3.3 All stroke patients should be assessed Australia, Australian Clinical Guidelines for Stroke\nManagement; CSBPR, Canadian Best Practices Recommendations; FIM, Functional Independence Measure; HQO, Health Quality Ontario;\nOSN, Ontario Stroke Network; where possible, these tools should be in electronic format linked to the EHR\n• Patients should be screened/assessed for diabetes, dental issues, cognitive impairment, and depression upon\npresentation to the ED, and the results should be forwarded to the TIA clinic for follow-up\n• Hospitals should ensure adequate staffing 7 days per week\nAbbreviations: ED, emergency department; This ensures that mobilization is not delayed and aligns with best practice guidelines.", 'format': "\nWhen the process starts, please output ''\nAn activity is represented as follows:\n\nThe exclusive gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nThe parallel gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nThe inclusive gateway is represented as follows:\n\n  \n    \n  \n  \n    \n  \n\nAt the end of the process, please output ''\n\nThere are a few requirements that should be noted when generating process text:\n    1) role, action, objects and id in an activity represent the subject of the activity, the activity behavior, the items needed to perform in the activity and the activity id, respectively.\n    2) There are at least two branches within the exclusive gateway and the parallel gateway.\n    3) Activity, gateway, and branch id attributes must be unique.\n    4) When the branch in the exclusive gateway has a condition, fill the condition into the condition attribute.
